nodes.text: Economic decision-making and market dynamics can be modeled using a quantum-inspired propensity framework where agents are described by propensity functions expressible in quantum probability and quantum-computing terms

Classical neoclassical economics models agents as utility-optimizers with fixed preferences and stable equilibria, but empirical cognitive phenomena (e.g., preference reversal, disjunction effect, order effects) violate these assumptions
Quantum probability uses a 2-norm, complex amplitudes, superposition, interference, and entanglement which naturally capture nonadditivity and noncommutativity observed in human decision behavior

Replace utility functions with propensity functions that give transaction probabilities; these propensity functions can be generated or represented by quantum wavefunctions so probabilities equal squared amplitudes

A simple two-qubit quantum circuit (unitary rotations A and B plus a C-NOT entangling gate) is equivalent to sequential projective measurements and can simulate order effects, disjunction effects, preference reversal, and social entanglement
Propensity functions allow definition of an entropic force f(x)=gamma P'(x)/P(x) which interprets tendencies toward maximum entropy as dynamics acting on mental states and prices

The two-qubit circuit output probabilities reproduce the joint and conditional probabilities of sequential yes/no question orders, demonstrating the order effect (quantitative expressions given in tables and derivable from unitary rotations)

A normal-shaped propensity function corresponds to the ground-state wavefunction of a quantum harmonic oscillator; the associated entropic force is linear (spring-like) F(x) = -k(x-mu) with k = gamma / sigma^2
The circuit equivalence holds for arbitrary unitary matrices A and B (Appendix derivation), so the quantum-circuit method is flexible and general for modeling context-dependent decisions

Quantization yields an economic mass m = hbar / (2 omega sigma^2) inversely related to propensity variance, and energy scale gamma = hbar omega^2 linking information, resistance to change, and mean-reversion frequency

The information or energy required to change preferences (preference reversal) depends on propensity ratios and approximates Delta E = (hbar omega / 2) log(3) approximately equal to hbar omega / 2 for a typical factor-3 change

Threshold effects arise because random subjective/contextual factors (gate A) can balance objective factors (gate B), producing switch-like changes in decisions; empirically preference reversal occurs when cost ratio x2/x1 > 3

The quantum propensity framework provides consistent units and dynamics (forces, mass, energy) to describe supply and demand and the flow of information in financial transactions, enabling simulation of option pricing and market statistics
Quantum methods better accommodate cognitive phenomena that elude behavioural modifications of utility theory and allow objective and subjective factors to be treated on equal footing

Limitations and caveats include the philosophical objection that social power and mental energy may not be fully reducible to precise equations, and empirical validation remains necessary though some criteria (e.g., preference reversal threshold) have empirical support
